title: 103_hr2328
content:
The "Public Lands Corps Act of 1993" is cited as the short title for this Act. Congressional findings and purpose are outlined in the following sections. The Congress finds that conserving natural and cultural resources through a Public Lands Corps can benefit young men and women by providing education and work opportunities, while also benefiting the economy and environment by rehabilitating degraded public lands and resources. The Public Lands Corps aims to provide education and work opportunities for young individuals to repay education debts, benefit the economy, and restore degraded public lands and resources through cost-effective conservation efforts. The Public Lands Corps aims to perform cost-effective conservation work on public and Indian lands, assist government agencies, expose youth to public service, and expand educational opportunities. The Public Lands Corps aims to involve young men and women in public service, increase their understanding of natural and cultural resources, provide educational opportunities, and stimulate interest in conservation careers. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "Corps" refers to the Public Lands Corps, the term "public lands" refers to lands owned or administered by the United States, and the term "qualified youth or conservation corps" refers to programs offering work for individuals between 16 and 25 years old in natural or cultural resource settings. The Public Lands Corps offers work opportunities for individuals aged 16-25 in natural or cultural resource settings, providing a mix of work experience, skills training, education, and support services. Participants also have the chance to develop citizenship values and skills through community service. The term "Indian tribe" includes recognized tribes by the Secretary of the Interior, as well as Native village corporations and groups established under the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act. The term "Indian" refers to a member of a tribe. The term "Indian lands" refers to real property owned by Indian tribes, held in trust by the United States, or subject to restrictions on alienation. The term "State" includes all states of the United States, territories, and commonwealths. The term "State" encompasses all states of the United States, territories, and commonwealths. A "conservation, restoration, or rehabilitation project" refers to any project aimed at preserving natural, cultural, historic, archaeological, recreational, or scenic resources. The Public Lands Corps Program is established. Establishment of Public Lands Corps in the Department of the Interior and Agriculture for young men and women aged 16-25. Enrolled individuals must be citizens or permanent residents of the US, possess a high school diploma or equivalent, and not have dropped out of school. Enrollees are exempt from civil service laws. The Public Lands Corps allows young individuals aged 16-25 with a high school diploma or equivalent to enroll without regard to civil service laws. The Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture can contract with qualified youth or conservation corps for conservation projects on public or Indian lands. The Secretary of Agriculture can utilize the Public Lands Corps or qualified youth/conservation corps for conservation projects on public or Indian lands. Preference is given to projects with long-term public benefits, instilling work ethic, being labor-intensive, prompt initiation, and providing educational opportunities. All projects must be consistent with the provisions of the Act. The Public Lands Corps or qualified youth/conservation corps can be utilized by the Secretary of Agriculture for conservation projects on public or Indian lands. Projects should prioritize long-term public benefits, work ethic, labor intensity, prompt initiation, and educational opportunities. All projects must align with relevant laws and policies governing the administration of the area. The Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture are authorized to provide necessary services and facilities for these programs. The Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture are authorized to provide necessary services and facilities for conservation projects, including establishing conservation centers with basic health and safety standards. They may also arrange logistical support from military installations near the centers. The Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture can establish conservation centers near military installations, providing temporary shelters, transportation, and supervision. They must set health, nutrition, sanitation, and safety standards for the centers and ensure compliance. Contracts with state, local agencies, and private organizations can be made for center management. SEC. 5. RESOURCE ASSISTANTS. The Resource Assistant Program authorizes the placement of qualified college students or recent graduates in Federal land managing agencies to conduct research or technical functions. Participants are recruited from colleges nationwide, with a focus on diversity. The program aims to serve two purposes. The Resource Assistant Program recruits college students and recent graduates from diverse backgrounds to work in Federal land managing agencies. The program aims to augment the agency's workforce and provide participants with exposure to potential conservation careers. Existing nonprofit organizations may also be utilized to fulfill program requirements. The agency can implement the program through existing nonprofit organizations, which must contribute 25% of the costs for interns from private funding sources. Participating organizations must submit annual reports evaluating the program's impact. The Resource Assistant program requires nonprofit conservation service organizations to contribute 25% of total costs for each participant recruited and placed. They must submit annual reports evaluating the program's scope, size, and quality, including the value of work contributed to the agency's mission. SEC. 6. Living allowances and terms of service for participants. Living allowances and terms of service are provided to participants in the Public Lands Corps and Resource Assistants. The living allowance cannot exceed the maximum established for participants in the national service program. Participants agree to a term of service determined by the Secretary of the Interior or Agriculture, consistent with the national service program requirements. Participants in the Public Lands Corps and Resource Assistants receive educational benefits or awards. Participants in the Public Lands Corps and Resource Assistants are eligible for national service awards under the National and Community Service Act of 1990. They may also receive forbearance in the collection of Stafford Loans under the Higher Education Act of 1965. Participants in the Public Lands Corps and Resource Assistants can receive forbearance on Stafford Loans under the Higher Education Act of 1965 while serving, based on regulations, and being eligible for post-service educational benefits or awards. SEC. 8. NONDISPLACEMENT. The nondisplacement requirements of the National and Community Service Act of 1990 apply to all activities of the Public Lands Corps and qualified youth or conservation corps under this Act. SEC. 9. FUNDING. Cost Sharing:
- The Secretary of the Interior and the Secretary of Agriculture can pay up to 75% of project costs on public lands by qualified youth or conservation corps.
- The remaining 25% can come from nonfederal sources.
- No cost sharing required for projects on Indian lands.
- Foundations associated with Federal land managing agencies can contribute to Public Lands Corps project costs. The Public Lands Corps established under this Act can receive contributions from foundations associated with Federal land managing agencies for project costs. The Secretary of the Interior and the Secretary of Agriculture are eligible to receive funds for programs under the National and Community Service Act without any cost-sharing requirements. Agriculture is eligible to receive funds under the National and Community Service Act of 1990 without restrictions, and there are authorized appropriations for this purpose.
